elements.content: One-dimensional (1-D) zigzag chains of {[AgL](ClO4)­·0.5Et2O} n (1), {[AgL](OTf)·Et2O} n (2), and {[AgL](BF4)­·0.5CH3OH} n (3) were obtained from the reaction of AgClO4, AgCF3SO3, and AgBF4 with 1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)­benzene (L), respectively, in similar reaction conditions, whereas it led to the formation of a 1-D sinusoidal chain of {[AgL(NO3)]·H2O} n (4) and a metallolocycle of [Ag2 L 6](BF4)2 (5) in a different reaction procedure for the AgNO3 and AgBF4 cases. Complexes 1–3 form 1-D zigzag chains, and every two chains are further stacked to give a pair of chains assisted by weak Ag(I)···Ag(I) and π···π interactions, whereas a single 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 can only be obtained. Although the reaction is carried out in a similar reaction as 4 except that BF4 – was used instead of NO3 –, a metallocycle of 5 was obtained instead. It is noted that only the bridging L ligands in 5 adopt a syn conformation, whereas those in 1–4 are in an anti conformation. In this regard, this work has demonstrated the delicate effects of anions and reaction conditions on the assembly reactions of complexes 1–5. In addition, we observed a structural transformation during the heating process for 5. Although the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 5 at 210 °C is similar to that of 3, it cannot be conclusively proven by powder X-ray diffraction studies at this moment due to the presence of some mismatches between both patterns of 5 and 3.

elements.content: Dipyridyl ligands with long and conjugated moieties have been utilized for the generation of a variety of supramolecular architectures and coordination frameworks, and these usually display interesting van der Waals, π···π, hydrogen-bonding, and other weak interactions in crystal lattices. In fact, these weak interactions can possibly influence the structural motifs or increase the structural complexities and cause interesting photophysical and -chemical phenomena due to orbital interactions between the π-conjugated systems of adjacent complexes. Moreover, the dipyridyl ligands with flexible spacers can act as either a chelating mode or a bridging one for the formation of metal-containing chains or macrocyclic compounds. Depending on the nature of the spacer’s moieties, reaction condition, and various metal ions, the metal-dipyridyl compounds are anticipated to exhibit a wide range of structural motifs with various coordination modes as well as practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Dipyridyl ligands with long and conjugated moieties have been utilized for the generation of a variety of supramolecular architectures and coordination frameworks, and these usually display interesting van der Waals, π⋅⋅⋅π, hydrogen-bonding, and other weak interactions in crystal lattices. In fact, these weak interactions can possibly influence the structural motifs or increase the structural complexities and cause interesting photophysical and -chemical phenomena due to orbital interactions between the π-conjugated systems of adjacent complexes. Moreover, the dipyridyl ligands with flexible spacers can act as either a chelating mode or a bridging one for the formation of metal-containing chains or macrocyclic compounds. Depending on the nature of the spacer's moieties, reaction condition, and various metal ions, the metal-dipyridyl compounds are anticipated to exhibit a wide range of structural motifs with various coordination modes as well as practical applications.

elements.content: The combination of benzene and acetylene linkers may increase the polarization properties that are expected to afford intermolecular metal/C–H···π interactions. In addition, the use of ethynyl spacer units in the dipyridy ligands may reduce the steric interactions between the metal–ligand moieties of the framework structures, and hence it is possible to allow the formation of chains and essentially planar macrocycles. This will help the complexes stack (i.e., metal···metal, π···π, or metal···π interactions) in the solid state and/or exhibit interesting spectroscopic properties.
elements.clean_text: The combination of benzene and acetylene linkers may increase the polarization properties that are expected to afford intermolecular metal/C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. In addition, the use of ethynyl spacer units in the dipyridy ligands may reduce the steric interactions between the metal-ligand moieties of the framework structures, and hence it is possible to allow the formation of chains and essentially planar macrocycles. This will help the complexes stack (i.e., metal⋅⋅⋅metal, π⋅⋅⋅π, or metal⋅⋅⋅π interactions) in the solid state and/or exhibit interesting spectroscopic properties.

elements.content: The interesting feature is that the Ag(I) ion can adopt various coordination numbers ranging from 2 to 6 without any strong energetic preference for the particular geometry. The availability of a wide range of Ag(I) salts provides a straightforward access to study the effect of the anions on the structures of coordination networks. In addition, weak d10···d10 interactions can also have a structure-directing effect. In 2000, Schröder et al. were the first to use the long and rigid linker 1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)­benzene (pyphe) to synthesize a one-dimensional (1-D) Ag(I) chain, {[Ag(pyphe)]PF6­·MeCN} n , and both chains are further connected by weak Ag(I)···π interactions (3.273(3) Å). Surprisingly, a long Ag(I)···Ag(I) distance of 5.177(3) Å was observed in such a Ag(I) complex, although there are several examples reported to have close Ag(I)···Ag(I) contacts in some Ag(I)-dipyridyl systems. Recently, Crowley et al. also reported an interesting family of planar dinuclear and trinuclear Ag(I)-dipyridyl metallocycles by reacting AgX (X = ClO4 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, and NO3 –) with 1,4-di(pyridin-3-yl)­buta-1,3-diyne or 1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)­benzene (L) respectively, which have been well characterized by HR-ESI-MS, and the solution data are consistent with the formation of the Ag(I)-dipyridyl metallocycle structures. X-ray crystallographic studies showed one of the Ag(I)-1,4-di(pyridin-3-yl)­buta-1,3-diyne complexes underwent the ring-opening process and crystallized as 1-D chains, presumably due to the lability of the Ag(I) ions. Rearrangement of coordination networks via a dissolution/precipitation pathway is well established, and structural transformation of coordination frameworks is an interesting phenomenon for their potential applications as switches and sensors. However, solid-state transformation is less common, since it typically involves a change in the metal coordination environments.

elements.content: Following Crowley’s interesting work, we would like to extend their studies and understand the solid-state structural properties for the Ag(I)-1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)­benzene complexes. In fact, their solution structures are well characterized by HR-ESI-MS, but no solid-state structure has been reported so far. This report is also inspired by the advantages of the Ag(I) ion with various coordination numbers and coordination geometries as well as the influence of anions and reaction conditions on the structural frameworks, and hence we set out to investigate the self-assembly behavior of various AgX (X = ClO4 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, and NO3 –) salts with the rigid ligand 1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)­benzene (L).

elements.content: 1,4-Bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)­benzene (L) was synthesized by the literature method. All solvents for syntheses (analytical grade) were used without further purification. (Caution! Perchlorate salts are potentially explosive and should be handled with care and in small amounts.) NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 400 MHz NMR spectrometer, and samples were prepared in deuterated solvents with the usual standards. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded with samples in the form of KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer PC 16 FTIR spectrometer. Solid-state emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. Elemental analysis (EA) of the complexes was performed on an Elementar vario EL III Heraeus CHNOS Rapid F002 elemental analyzer. The ESI mass measurements were only carried out in the CH3CN solution of AgX and L with a 1:1 ratio, and the mass data are also consistent with the Crowley’s solution data, indicative of the presence of Ag(I)-dipyridyl metallocycles ().
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

1,4-Bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)benzene (L) was synthesized by the literature method. All solvents for syntheses (analytical grade) were used without further purification. (Caution! Perchlorate salts are potentially explosive and should be handled with care and in small amounts.) NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 400 MHz NMR spectrometer, and samples were prepared in deuterated solvents with the usual standards. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded with samples in the form of KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer PC 16 FTIR spectrometer. Solid-state emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. Elemental analysis (EA) of the complexes was performed on an Elementar vario EL III Heraeus CHNOS Rapid F002 elemental analyzer. The ESI mass measurements were only carried out in the CH3CN solution of AgX and L with a 1:1 ratio, and the mass data are also consistent with the Crowley's solution data, indicative of the presence of Ag(I)-dipyridyl metallocycles ().

elements.content: To a solution of L (7.01 mg, 0.025 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (7 mL), AgClO4 (5.70 mg, 0.025 mmol) in CH3CN (3.5 mL) was added dropwise. elements.content: Suitable single crystals were mounted on glass capillaries. Data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with Mo radiation (0.71073 Å) at 150(2), 220(2), 150(2), 100(2), and 100(2) °C for complexes 1–5, respectively. A preliminary orientation matrix and unit cell parameters were determined from three runs of 15 frames each, with each frame corresponding to 0.3° scan in 20 s, followed by spot integration and least-squares refinement. Data were measured using an ω scan of 0.3° per frame for 20 s until a complete hemisphere had been collected. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Data reduction was performed with the SAINT software and corrected for Lorentz and Polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atomic positions were located in difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to the ideal geometry using an appropriate riding model. Detailed data collection and refinement of 1–5 are summarized in Table , and the bond distances and angles are shown in Table .

X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals were mounted on glass capillaries. Data collection was carried out on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer with Mo radiation (0.71073 Å) at 150(2), 220(2), 150(2), 100(2), and 100(2) °C for complexes 1-5, respectively. A preliminary orientation matrix and unit cell parameters were determined from three runs of 15 frames each, with each frame corresponding to 0.3° scan in 20 s, followed by spot integration and least-squares refinement. Data were measured using an ω scan of 0.3° per frame for 20 s until a complete hemisphere had been collected. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined with SAINT on all observed reflections. Data reduction was performed with the SAINT software and corrected for Lorentz and Polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied with the program SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atomic positions were located in difference Fourier maps and refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to the ideal geometry using an appropriate riding model. Detailed data collection and refinement of 1-5 are summarized in Table , and the bond distances and angles are shown in Table .

In this work, we report the synthesis and structural properties of four 1-D Ag(I) chains and a metallocycle containing 1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)benzene (L). As expected, the rigid acetylene spacer between the pyridine and the benzene rings allows the possibility of pyridyl rings of L to adopt either a syn or anti conformation. Besides the effect of the ligand, we have also tried to examine the effects of various Ag(I) salts and reaction conditions on their structural formation. In this regard, complexes 1–5 were synthesized by reacting AgX (X = ClO4 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, and NO3 –) with 1,4-bis[(3-pyridyl)ethynyl]­benzene (L), respectively. Here, 1-D zigzag chains of 1–3 were obtained for AgClO4, AgCF3SO3, and AgBF4 in a similar reaction condition, whereas it led to the formation of a 1-D sinusoidal chain (4) and a metallolocycle (5) in a different reaction procedure for AgNO3 and AgBF4, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

In this work, we report the synthesis and structural properties of four 1-D Ag(I) chains and a metallocycle containing 1,4-bis(pyridine-3-ylethynyl)benzene (L). As expected, the rigid acetylene spacer between the pyridine and the benzene rings allows the possibility of pyridyl rings of L to adopt either a syn or anti conformation. Besides the effect of the ligand, we have also tried to examine the effects of various Ag(I) salts and reaction conditions on their structural formation. In this regard, complexes 1-5 were synthesized by reacting AgX (X = ClO4 -, CF3SO3 -, BF4 -, and NO3 -) with 1,4-bis[(3-pyridyl)ethynyl]benzene (L), respectively. Here, 1-D zigzag chains of 1-3 were obtained for AgClO4, AgCF3SO3, and AgBF4 in a similar reaction condition, whereas it led to the formation of a 1-D sinusoidal chain (4) and a metallolocycle (5) in a different reaction procedure for AgNO3 and AgBF4, respectively.

elements.content: Since the structural motifs of 1–3 are quite similar, we only choose 1 as a representative example for detailed structural description, and the related parameters of weak interactions are summarized in Table . The X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 revealed that it crystallized in the triclinic space group of P1̅, and the Ag(I) ion coordinates to two bridging L ligands through pyridine-coordination (Ag–N = 2.153(2) and 2.153(2) Å) with an almost linear geometry (173.22(8)°) as shown in Figure , leading to the formation of a 1-D zigzag chain. Additionally, every two zigzag chains are stacked on each other with a short Ag(I)···Ag(I) distance of 3.2487(4) Å and weak π···π interactions between pyridyl–pyridyl rings (3.638 Å) as well as benzene–benzene rings (3.831 Å). It is noted that such a short Ag(I)···Ag(I) contact is significantly shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii (3.44 Å), indicative of the presence of argentophilic interactions in the solid state. In addition to short Ag(I)···Ag(I) and π···π contacts for each paired chains, there are weak Ag(I)···ClO4 interactions (2.824 and 2.856 Å) ClO4 – anions entrapped within two zigzag chains. Moreover, each paired chain shows a close Ag(I)···π (alkyne) contact of 3.482 Å with neighboring pairs, which is comparable to the sum of van der Waals radii (3.442 Å). The related Ag(I)···Ag(I) and π···π contacts are found in 2 and 3 as well, and the distances are summarized in Table . Indeed, the above Ag(I)···Ag(I) distances (3.2487(4) Å in 1, 3.3041(12) Å in 2, and 3.2572(8) Å in 3) are comparable with those of 3.1929(10)–3.312(1) Å in some Ag(I)-dipyridyl systems. The distances of Ag(I)···O (OTf–) for 2 and Ag(I)···F (BF4 –) for 3 are found to be 2.740(4) and 2.984(7)/3.005(5) Å, respectively. Although a short Ag(I)···π (alkyne) contact of 3.174 Å for 3 is observed, no such contact (longer than 4.0 Å) can be found for 2. It is somewhat surprising that in {[Ag(pyphe)]PF 6 ­·MeCN} n the Ag(I)-pyphe chains significantly shifted with respect to each other leading to a long Ag(I)···Ag distance of 5.177(3) Å. Although this may be considered as an effect of the electrostatic repulsion of the cations, similar structural backbones of 1–3 with an isomeric analogue of pyphe showed close Ag(I)···Ag(I) contacts. Thus, stacking interactions possibly play an important role in the structural arrangement.

Complex 4 crystallized in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The Ag(I) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinating to one μ2-nitrate anion (Ag–O = 2.6896(19) Å) as well as two bridging L ligands through pyridine-coordination (Ag–N = 2.2042(18) Å), giving a 1-D sinusoidal chain as shown in Figure . Unlike those of 1–3 with an almost linear geometry of Ag(I) (173.22(8), 175.23(19), and 173.13(16)° for 1, 2, and 3, respectively), the N–Ag–N angle of 151.19(10)° in 4 significantly deviates from the linearity because of nitrate binding. Despite the observation of slipped stacking of the 1-D chains facilitated by the long Ag(I)···π (alkyne/pyridine) contact of 3.674/3.421 Å and hydrogen bonding between the water and coordinated nitrate anions (O···O 2.8632(15) Å) to give a 3-D supramolecular motif, there is no close Ag(I)···Ag(I) (the closest intermolecular Ag(I)···Ag(I) distance is 5.249 Å) and π···π contact observed in crystal lattices. Thus, it can be concluded that 4 forms only a single sinusoidal chain instead of those paired chains found in 1–3.

Crystal Structure of {[AgL(NO3)]⋅H2O]} n  (4)

Complex 4 crystallized in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The Ag(I) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinating to one μ2-nitrate anion (Ag-O = 2.6896(19) Å) as well as two bridging L ligands through pyridine-coordination (Ag-N = 2.2042(18) Å), giving a 1-D sinusoidal chain as shown in Figure . Unlike those of 1-3 with an almost linear geometry of Ag(I) (173.22(8), 175.23(19), and 173.13(16)° for 1, 2, and 3, respectively), the N-Ag-N angle of 151.19(10)° in 4 significantly deviates from the linearity because of nitrate binding. Despite the observation of slipped stacking of the 1-D chains facilitated by the long Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅π (alkyne/pyridine) contact of 3.674/3.421 Å and hydrogen bonding between the water and coordinated nitrate anions (O⋅⋅⋅O 2.8632(15) Å) to give a 3-D supramolecular motif, there is no close Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅Ag(I) (the closest intermolecular Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅Ag(I) distance is 5.249 Å) and π⋅⋅⋅π contact observed in crystal lattices. Thus, it can be concluded that 4 forms only a single sinusoidal chain instead of those paired chains found in 1-3.

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallized in the triclinic space group of P1̅, and the X-ray diffraction shows that 5 forms a 30-membered metallocycle, constructed from two Ag(I) ions and two bridging L ligands through pyridine-coordination as shown in Figure (a). Besides two bridging L ligands, each Ag(I) ion additionally coordinates to two L as terminal ligands. The Ag–N bond distances (2.2725(15)–2.4680(15) Å) and the N–Ag–N bond angles (97.08(5)–133.65(5)°) suggest that each Ag(I) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry. As expected, the long ethynyl spacer allows the possibility of pyridyl rings of L to adopt either a syn or anti conformation. Hence, the bridging L ligands in 5 adopt a syn conformation for a metallocyclic structure, whereas those in 1-D chains of 1–4 are in an anti conformation. In addition, the supramolecular structure of 5 is assisted by multiple weak π···π interactions (3.639–3.843 Å) in crystal lattices (see Figure b and Table ), and the two BF4 – anions sit slightly above and below the metallocyclic plane.

Crystal Structure of [Ag2L6](BF4)2 (5)

Complex 5 crystallized in the triclinic space group of P1̅, and the X-ray diffraction shows that 5 forms a 30-membered metallocycle, constructed from two Ag(I) ions and two bridging L ligands through pyridine-coordination as shown in Figure (a). Besides two bridging L ligands, each Ag(I) ion additionally coordinates to two L as terminal ligands. The Ag-N bond distances (2.2725(15)-2.4680(15) Å) and the N-Ag-N bond angles (97.08(5)-133.65(5)°) suggest that each Ag(I) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry. As expected, the long ethynyl spacer allows the possibility of pyridyl rings of L to adopt either a syn or anti conformation. Hence, the bridging L ligands in 5 adopt a syn conformation for a metallocyclic structure, whereas those in 1-D chains of 1-4 are in an anti conformation. In addition, the supramolecular structure of 5 is assisted by multiple weak π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (3.639-3.843 Å) in crystal lattices (see Figure b and Table ), and the two BF4 - anions sit slightly above and below the metallocyclic plane.

elements.content: Complexes 1–3 were synthesized in a similar way, and their single crystals were grown from ether diffusion into the respective solutions. On the basis of X-ray diffraction studies, every two 1-D zigzag chains in 1–3 are stacked on each other by Ag(I)···Ag(I) and π···π interactions and also connected with bridging anions. No anion effect is found in this series, although this is a common phenomenon for the Ag(I) complexes. However, 4 and 5 were prepared in a different way compared to 1–3. Actually, 4 is only a single sinusoidal chain instead of those paired chains of 1–3, where the Ag(I)···π (alkyne) and hydrogen-bonding interactions between the water and coordinated nitrate anions can be observed. Even in a similar reaction condition except that BF4 – is used instead of NO3 –, only a dinuclear metallocycle of 5 can be obtained. Thus, we have demonstrated the delicate effects of anions and reaction conditions on the assembly reactions of complexes 1–5. In addition, this work can also provide some structural evidence in the solid state for comparison with Crowley’s solution data.

On the basis of X-ray diffraction studies, every two 1-D zigzag chains in 1-3 are stacked on each other by Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅Ag(I) and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions and also connected with bridging anions. No anion effect is found in this series, although this is a common phenomenon for the Ag(I) complexes. However, 4 and 5 were prepared in a different way compared to 1-3. Actually, 4 is only a single sinusoidal chain instead of those paired chains of 1-3, where the Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅π (alkyne) and hydrogen-bonding interactions between the water and coordinated nitrate anions can be observed. Even in a similar reaction condition except that BF4 - is used instead of NO3 -, only a dinuclear metallocycle of 5 can be obtained. Thus, we have demonstrated the delicate effects of anions and reaction conditions on the assembly reactions of complexes 1-5. In addition, this work can also provide some structural evidence in the solid state for comparison with Crowley's solution data.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Figure has been conducted to examine the thermostabilities of complexes 2–5 (unfortunately, we cannot obtain the TGA data of 1, since there is an explosive problem during the experimental measurement). There is not any weight loss before 350 °C for 2 (although there is solvated Et2O in crystal lattices, it should escape easily in air), and beyond this temperature it starts to decompose. In the case of 3, a 6.5% weight loss at 290 °C was found, and this can be ascribed to one water molecule and half a methanol molecule (6.6%), where one more water molecule may be explained by water sorption in air. As that of 2, it starts to decompose at 350 °C, indicating that both 1-D zigzag paired chains have quite similar thermostabilities. The weight loss of 3.6% for 4 at 208 °C fits with the one calculated water molecule loss in crystal lattices (3.8%), and it starts to decompose after this temperature. There is not any weight loss before 230 °C for 5 (no solvate in crystal lattices), and beyond this temperature it starts to decompose. In this regard, it is obvious that a 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 and a metallocycle of 5 are less stable than those paired chains of 2 and 3.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Studies

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Figure  has been conducted to examine the thermostabilities of complexes 2-5 (unfortunately, we cannot obtain the TGA data of 1, since there is an explosive problem during the experimental measurement). There is not any weight loss before 350 °C for 2 (although there is solvated Et2O in crystal lattices, it should escape easily in air), and beyond this temperature it starts to decompose. In the case of 3, a 6.5% weight loss at 290 °C was found, and this can be ascribed to one water molecule and half a methanol molecule (6.6%), where one more water molecule may be explained by water sorption in air. As that of 2, it starts to decompose at 350 °C, indicating that both 1-D zigzag paired chains have quite similar thermostabilities. The weight loss of 3.6% for 4 at 208 °C fits with the one calculated water molecule loss in crystal lattices (3.8%), and it starts to decompose after this temperature. There is not any weight loss before 230 °C for 5 (no solvate in crystal lattices), and beyond this temperature it starts to decompose. In this regard, it is obvious that a 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 and a metallocycle of 5 are less stable than those paired chains of 2 and 3.

elements.content: One-dimensional chains and metallocyclic structures for the Ag(I)-dipyridyl systems are not uncommon, but studies related to structural transformation between these two structural motifs are rare. Previously, we have been able to experimentally prove an example of crystal-to-crystal transformation by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) technique, where heating a molecular rectangle of [ZnI2(N,N′-bis-4-methyl-pyridyl oxalamide)]2 successfully gave a 1-D chain of [ZnI2(N,N′-bis-4-methyl-pyridyl oxalamide)] n . Thus, we set out to examine if 5 can undergo structural transformation from a metallocycle to a 1-D chain as shown in Figure . Upon heating solid samples of 5 to 170 °C, the PXRD patterns remained unchanged, and furthermore 5 undergoes a structural transformation while heating to 210 °C for 30 min. Although the new patterns look similar compared with the simulated one of 1-D zigzag chain of 3, unfortunately they are not completely identical. Thus, we cannot conclude such an interesting crystal-to-crystal transformation from a metallocycle of 5 to a 1-D zigzag chain of 3 occurred. However, some mismatches between both diffraction patterns due to the presence of amorphous or crystalline L ligands are still possible, since to reach the composition of 3 ([AgL] n n+) 5 ([Ag2 L 6]2+) must rearrange to give a mixed composition of [Ag2 L 2 + 4L]2+. Although at this moment structural transformation between 5 and 3 cannot be proven conclusively by PXRD studies, we did observe a structural transformation process.

However, some mismatches between both diffraction patterns due to the presence of amorphous or crystalline L ligands are still possible, since to reach the composition of 3 ([AgL] n   n+) 5 ([Ag2 L 6]2+) must rearrange to give a mixed composition of [Ag2 L 2 + 4L]2+. Although at this moment structural transformation between 5 and 3 cannot be proven conclusively by PXRD studies, we did observe a structural transformation process.

elements.content: Solid-state emission spectra of L and complexes 1–5 measured at room temperature are shown in Figure . The L ligand exhibits photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 448 nm, and complexes 1–5 display emission maxima at 445, 454, 454, 444, and 460 nm, respectively, upon excitation with wavelengths of 375–390 nm. Because of the high similarity for the above emissions, these emissions most likely have a similar excited state, namely, an intraligand transition of L. Interestingly, although Ag(I)···Ag(I) (3.2487(4)–3.3041(12) Å), π···π (3.623–3.653 and 3.728–3.831 Å), and some other weak interactions existing in 1–3 can be found in the solid state, such weak interactions seem not to exert any significant effect on their respective emissions.

elements.content: We have synthesized and structurally characterized a family of 1-D Ag(I) chains as well as a metalloclycle upon the reaction of 1,4-bis[(3-pyridyl)ethynyl]­benzene (L) with various AgX salts (X = ClO4 –, CF3SO3 –, BF4 –, and NO3 –). One-dimensional zigzag chains of 1–3 were obtained for the AgClO4, AgCF3SO3, and AgBF4 cases in a similar reaction condition, whereas it led to the formation of a 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 and a metallolocycle of 5 in a different reaction procedure for the AgNO3 and AgBF4 cases, respectively. Every two zigzag chains of 1–3 are stacked on each other with both weak Ag(I)···Ag(I) and π···π interactions, whereas the single 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 can be only obtained. Even in a similar reaction except that BF4 – was used instead of NO3 –, only a metallocycle of 5 was obtained. It is noted that the bridging L ligands in 5 adopt a syn conformation, whereas those in 1–4 are in an anti conformation. Thus, this work has demonstrated the delicate effects of anions and reaction conditions in the assembly reactions of complexes 1–5. In addition, upon heating solid samples of 5 to 210 °C, it undergoes structural transformation. Although the PXRD pattern is similar to that of 3, it can not be conclusively proven by PXRD studies at this moment due to the presence of some mismatches between both patterns of 5 and 3. However, we did observe a structural transformation during the heating process. This work can provide some structural evidence in the solid state for comparison with Crowley’s solution data.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have synthesized and structurally characterized a family of 1-D Ag(I) chains as well as a metalloclycle upon the reaction of 1,4-bis[(3-pyridyl)ethynyl]benzene (L) with various AgX salts (X = ClO4 -, CF3SO3 -, BF4 -, and NO3 -). One-dimensional zigzag chains of 1-3 were obtained for the AgClO4, AgCF3SO3, and AgBF4 cases in a similar reaction condition, whereas it led to the formation of a 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 and a metallolocycle of 5 in a different reaction procedure for the AgNO3 and AgBF4 cases, respectively. Every two zigzag chains of 1-3 are stacked on each other with both weak Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅Ag(I) and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, whereas the single 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 can be only obtained. Even in a similar reaction except that BF4 - was used instead of NO3 -, only a metallocycle of 5 was obtained. It is noted that the bridging L ligands in 5 adopt a syn conformation, whereas those in 1-4 are in an anti conformation. Thus, this work has demonstrated the delicate effects of anions and reaction conditions in the assembly reactions of complexes 1-5. In addition, upon heating solid samples of 5 to 210 °C, it undergoes structural transformation. Although the PXRD pattern is similar to that of 3, it can not be conclusively proven by PXRD studies at this moment due to the presence of some mismatches between both patterns of 5 and 3. However, we did observe a structural transformation during the heating process. This work can provide some structural evidence in the solid state for comparison with Crowley's solution data.

cln_elements.content:
The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) as shown in Figure has been conducted to examine the thermostabilities of complexes 2–5 (unfortunately, we cannot obtain the TGA data of 1, since there is an explosive problem during the experimental measurement). There is not any weight loss before 350 °C for 2 (although there is solvated Et2O in crystal lattices, it should escape easily in air), and beyond this temperature it starts to decompose. In the case of 3, a 6.5% weight loss at 290 °C was found, and this can be ascribed to one water molecule and half a methanol molecule (6.6%), where one more water molecule may be explained by water sorption in air. As that of 2, it starts to decompose at 350 °C, indicating that both 1-D zigzag paired chains have quite similar thermostabilities. The weight loss of 3.6% for 4 at 208 °C fits with the one calculated water molecule loss in crystal lattices (3.8%), and it starts to decompose after this temperature. There is not any weight loss before 230 °C for 5 (no solvate in crystal lattices), and beyond this temperature it starts to decompose. In this regard, it is obvious that a 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 and a metallocycle of 5 are less stable than those paired chains of 2 and 3.

Luminescent Properties

Solid-state emission spectra of L and complexes 1–5 measured at room temperature are shown in Figure . The L ligand exhibits photoluminescence with an emission maximum at 448 nm, and complexes 1–5 display emission maxima at 445, 454, 454, 444, and 460 nm, respectively, upon excitation with wavelengths of 375–390 nm. Because of the high similarity for the above emissions, these emissions most likely have a similar excited state, namely, an intraligand transition of L. Interestingly, although Ag(I)···Ag(I) (3.2487(4)–3.3041(12) Å), π···π (3.623–3.653 and 3.728–3.831 Å), and some other weak interactions existing in 1–3 can be found in the solid state, such weak interactions seem not to exert any significant effect on their respective emissions.

In this regard, it is obvious that a 1-D sinusoidal chain of 4 and a metallocycle of 5 are less stable than those paired chains of 2 and 3.
